newsitem.title: ISRAEL: Turkey's Demirel tells Israel deals are intact.
newsitem.headline: Turkey's Demirel tells Israel deals are intact.

text.p: Turkish President Suleyman Demirel said in remarks published on Sunday that defence and training pacts with Israel remained intact despite the rise of an Islamist-led government in Ankara.

"I am making clear: the Turkish-Israeli military cooperation, as with cooperation in all other areas, will continue in the future without interruption," he told the Israeli daily Haaretz in an interview in the Turkish capital.
Israel and Turkey signed an agreement in February allowing Israeli air force jets to train in Turkish air space.

The accord drew strong protests at the time from Islamists, whose leader Necmettin Erbakan has toned down his criticism since becoming prime minister 2-1/2 months ago. A month ago the two countries signed a defence industry cooperation deal.
Demirel said it was a mistake to call the present Turkish government "Islamist" since it was a coalition created in accordance with the law by two political parties represented in parliament.
"Moreover the principles of foreign policy of Turkey stay put," he said in the weekend interview.
Demirel said it was no secret that neighbouring countries such as Iran and Syria were worried. But he emphasised that neither accord was directed against a third country.

He reiterated Ankara's plans to set up a temporary security zone in northern Iraq to prevent infiltration by separatist rebels of the Kurdistan Workers Party (PKK) using bases there to launch attacks for self-rule in southeast Turkey.
Turkey had said the recent sweep of northern Iraq by another Baghdad-backed Kurdish faction, the Kurdistan Democratic Party (KDP), increased the need for a cordon.
"Because the recent events have made the authority vacuum worse in northern Iraq, Turkey stands by the need to take a series of steps in order to maintain its security and protect innocent citizens.
"In this framework we have decided to declare the zone parallel to our border at a depth of 5-15 kms (three to nine miles) a 'temporary danger zone'," he said.
He said there would be no permanent military presence but that intelligence and monitoring measures would be used.
Demirel also assailed what he called "Syria's support for the Kurdish terror of the PKK against Turkey."
He said: "Syria is interested in undermining the stability of and weakening Turkey. Damascus supports all the organisations whose purpose is to change the government in Turkey."
